title: 104_hr3058
content: The "Overseas Citizens Voting Rights Act of 1996" extends the period for receipt of absentee ballots and allows absentee ballots to be received until the close of polls on election day. It also extends federal write-in absentee ballot provisions to special, primary, and runoff elections. The Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act is amended to include special, primary, and runoff elections, as well as rules for general and special elections. Additionally, approved state absentee ballots can be used in place of federal write-in absentee ballots. The Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act is amended to include special, primary, and runoff elections, as well as rules for general and special elections. Certain states are exempted from the amendments, and the effective date for these changes is after December 31, 1996. SEC. 4. USE OF ELECTRONIC RETURN OF ABSENTEE BALLOTS. In consultation with the Presidential designee, Section 104 of the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act is amended to consider expeditious methods for returning absentee ballots, including electronic transmittal, while ensuring ballot secrecy and election integrity. The Voting Act is amended to ensure secrecy and verification of electronically transmitted ballots paid for with Federal funds. No person other than the voter can view a completed ballot, and the original ballot must be submitted in a secrecy envelope to the State location. SEC. 108 of the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act allows for the electronic transmission of balloting materials, ensuring secrecy and verification of electronically transmitted ballots paid for with Federal funds. Each State, in cooperation with the Presidential designee, must establish a system for electronic transmittal of balloting materials for overseas voters, allowing for electronic transmittal as an alternative method, use of official post card format for absentee voter registration, and furnishing of absentee ballots electronically to overseas voters. The Federal Government will cover additional costs for States implementing electronic transmittal of balloting materials for overseas voters. If full payment is not made, States can agree to partial payment to comply with the requirements. The State agrees to comply with requirements under the law. SEC. 109. NOTIFICATION REQUIREMENT FOR APPROVAL OF ELECTRONIC TRANSMITTAL METHOD. The Presidential designee must submit a detailed report to Congress 90 days before approving any electronic transmittal method under the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act. The definition of "electronic transmittal" is clarified to include facsimile machines or other approved electronic methods. The amendments made by this section shall apply to elections after December 31, 1996. SEC. 6. REPORT PROVISION. Amendment to the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act includes a separate analysis of electronic transmittal of balloting materials.
